No Other Amendment. Except as expressly provided herein, all terms of the Agreement remain in full force and effect, and nothing herein shall otherwise affect, amend or modify any provision of the Agreement or the respective rights and obligations of the Parties.

Counterparts. This Amendment may be executed in one or more counterparts, each of which when executed shall be deemed an original, but all of which when taken together shall constitute one and the same instrument.
Entirety. The Agreement (as amended hereby) constitutes the entire contract between the Parties hereto relative to the subject matter.
Governing Law. THIS AMENDMENT IS GOVERNED BY AND CONSTRUED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF TEXAS, WITHOUT REGARD TO THE CONFLICT OF LAWS PROVISIONS OF SUCH STATE.
Expenses. Each Party shall pay its own costs and expenses in connection with this Amendment (including the fees and expenses of its legal counsel).
Recitals. The Recitals to this Agreement are hereby incorporated and made a part hereof and are an integral part of this Amendment.

elements.title: Risks Related to Retaining Key Personnel

data.value: Failure to retain and attract key personnel such as Tellurian’s Executive Chairman, Vice Chairman, Chief Executive Officer or other skilled professional and technical employees could have an adverse effect on Tellurian’s business.
The success of Tellurian’s business relies heavily on key personnel such as its Executive Chairman, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.
Tellurian is dependent upon an available labor pool of skilled employees and will compete with other employers to attract and retain qualified personnel.
A shortage of skilled workers or inflationary pressures could increase operating costs, materially affecting financial condition.
Tellurian faces intense competition in the energy industry from larger firms with greater resources.
Due to the sharp decline in oil and natural gas prices and the negative economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

elements.title: Definitions of Oil and Gas Reserves

data.value: Proved oil and gas reserves are those quantities of oil and gas which are estimated to be economically producible from known reservoirs under existing economic conditions.

The economic conditions include prices and costs at which economic producibility from a reservoir is determined, defined as the average price during the 12-month period prior to the report's ending date.
Use of deterministic methods indicates a high degree of confidence, while probabilistic methods should show at least a 90% probability of quantities being met.
Technologies that have been field tested and produce consistently reliable results.
Reserves are estimated remaining quantities of oil and gas anticipated to be economically producible by applying development projects to known accumulations.

elements.title: Financial Statement of Revenues and Expenses

data.key: Net cash used in operating activities
Net cash used in investing activities
Net cash provided by financing activities
Cash, cash equivalents and restricted cash, end of period

data.value: Each LNG cargo is deemed to be a single performance obligation, with sales recognized at a point in time when the LNG has completed discharging to the customer.
Contracts with a fixed differential to an index price, deemed fixed consideration allocated to performance obligations.
LNG sales recorded on a gross basis and reported in 'LNG sales' on the Consolidated Statements of Operations.
Receivables consist primarily of trade receivables from natural gas sales and joint interest billings, with payment terms of 30 days or less.
All highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less are considered cash equivalents.
Used to hedge exposure to cash flow variability from commodity price risk, recorded at fair value.
Natural gas development accounted for using successful efforts method; costs capitalized when incurred.
Management tests for impairment whenever indicators suggest the carrying amount may not be recoverable.
The Company adopted the Accounting Standards Update ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842) on January 1, 2019.
Leases are recognized as either finance or operating leases on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
A lease liability for future payments and a right-of-use asset is recorded.
Operating lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
Substantially all costs related to LNG Development Activities have been expensed.
Costs incurred to develop the project are capitalized once certain criteria (regulatory permits, financing secured, management commitment) are met.
Interest is capitalized in connection with the construction of major facilities.
Debt discounts and expenses are amortized over the term of the debt.
Share-based compensation includes stock options and is measured based on the grant-date estimated fair value.

data.value: In conjunction with the dismissal of prior litigation, the Company reimbursed Vice Chairman Martin Houston for attorneys’ fees totaling approximately $5.1 million during 2020 and additional payments of $0.9 million and $1.4 million for 2021 and 2020 respectively.
The Company entered into a one-year contractor agreement with Mr. Houston, paying him $50,000 monthly, which was increased to $55,000 in December 2022.
Total increased from $85,946 in 2021 to $129,180 in 2022, with a notable increase in Driftwood Project liabilities.
Total borrowings amount to $557,678 in principal with a carrying value of $545,764.

elements.title: Critical Audit Matter Addressed in Audit

We evaluated the reasonableness of management’s five-year development plan.
We evaluated the reasonableness of natural gas prices by comparing to third party industry sources and historical prices.

We evaluated the Company's estimates around production volumes by comparing to past production performance.
We evaluated the experience and objectivity of management’s specialist in estimating natural gas reserves.

elements.title: Approval Requirements for Changes to the Indenture and Notes

data.key: Changes Requiring Approval of Each Holder
data.value: Changes requiring specific approval from each holder include changing the stated maturity of the principal or interest, reducing the principal amount or rate of interest, changing the payment place, impairing suit rights for payments, and altering consent percentages.
Any other change requires approval from holders of not less than a majority in principal amount of the outstanding Notes or respective series affected.
Outstanding Notes for voting include all authenticated and delivered Notes, with exceptions for cancelled Notes, Notes set aside for payment or redemption, and certain other categorized Notes.

elements.title: Regulatory Authority of FERC Over Natural Gas Transportation

data.value: FERC's jurisdiction under the NGA involves the transportation of natural gas in interstate commerce and the sale in interstate commerce of natural gas for resale.
On January 19, 2021, FERC granted a waiver for buy/sell arrangements for future transactions involving LNG.
A certificate of public convenience and necessity is required for construction and operation of facilities used in interstate natural gas transportation.
FERC applies light-handed regulation to LNG terminalling services as per its longstanding policy.
The Company filed an application for a certificate to construct and operate new pipelines, with the final order on the application still pending.
It is unlawful for any entity to use deceptive or manipulative devices in connection with regulated natural gas transactions.
FERC has authority to impose civil penalties for violations exceeding $1 million per day.
On February 18, 2022, FERC issued policy statements for assessing new transportation projects and their public convenience.

elements.title: Federal and State Regulation of Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety

data.value: FERC is reissuing policy statements as drafts for comments on infrastructure projects regarding climate change.
Authorization to export LNG in a volume up to 1,415.3 Bcf per year to FTA countries for 30 years.
The Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 (NGPSA) authorizes DOT to regulate pipeline transportation of natural gas.
Pipeline companies must perform integrity tests on a seven-year cycle for pipelines in high population areas.
The Act reauthorizes the PHMSA pipeline safety program and directs updates to current regulations for LNG facilities.
PHMSA updated federal pipeline safety regulations to reduce regulatory burdens and improve safety requirements.

data.value: Establishes a federal inter-agency working group for the social cost of carbon.

Requires environmental reviews for proposed projects.
Restricts emissions and imposes monitoring requirements.
Subject to federal and state air quality regulations.
Significant new requirements to reduce air emissions.
Proposed revisions to annual PM2.5 standard.
Focuses on advancing environmental justice in federal decision-making.
Imposes fees on methane emissions from specified facilities.
Ensures consistency of coastal area impacts.

Regulates generation, handling and disposal of solid and hazardous waste.
Imposes liability for hazardous substance release without regard to fault.

data.value: Hydraulic fracturing is subject to state and federal regulations, with potential new regulatory programs from the EPA affecting operations.
The company has agreed to indemnify sellers against environmental claims, potentially incurring future remediation costs.
New regulations may slow permitting processes and increase operational costs.
Operations may be restricted under ESA, requiring consultations to avoid harm to protected species.
Regulations prohibit sending wastewater pollutants to publicly-owned treatment works, necessitating additional permits.
The company must consult with federal agencies under NEPA regarding potential impacts on threatened or endangered species.
State laws regulate the size and shape of drilling and spacing units.
Some states allow forced pooling or integration of tracts.
State conservation laws establish maximum rates of production.
States impose production, ad valorem, or severance tax.
Subject to laws like the FCPA, U.K. Bribery Act.
Regulations from various government entities govern international operations.

On March 24, 2022, the Company issued a limited notice to proceed to Bechtel Energy Inc., formerly known as Bechtel Oil, Gas and Chemicals, Inc. under our LSTK EPC agreement for Phase 1 of the Driftwood terminal.
On June 3, 2022, we issued and sold $500.0 million aggregate principal amount of 6.00% Senior Secured Convertible Notes due May 1, 2025.
On August 18, 2022, the Company completed the acquisition of certain natural gas assets in the Haynesville Shale basin for an adjusted purchase price of approximately $133.8 million.

During the year ended December 31, 2021, the Company entered into a pledge with the National Forest Foundation on a five-year plan for reforestation and other forest management projects totaling $25.0 million.
In 2022, the Company supported the planting of more than one million trees on 1,441 acres across the United States.
The Company bolstered nursery capacity by 1 million seedlings.
